channel.title: BBC News | Technology | UK Edition
channel.description: Visit BBC News for up-to-the-minute news, breaking news, video, audio and feature stories. BBC News provides trusted World and UK news as well as local and regional perspectives. Also entertainment, business, science, technology and health news.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse

item.title: Firm 'sold workers' secret data'
item.description: A company that allegedly sold workers' personal details to building firms is to be prosecuted by the information watchdog.

item.title: Obama picks US information chief
item.description: Vivek Kundra has been picked by President Obama as his chief information officer.

item.title: Al Gore says domain .eco logical
item.description: Former US vice president AL Gore is backing the creation of green .eco domain names.

item.title: User info stolen from music site
item.description: Fraudsters have hacked in and stolen the personal details of thousands of users from the music streaming website Spotify.

item.title: Tech support calls can be costly
item.description: A survey by Which computing has found that the majority of tech firms use premium rate helplines for technical support.

item.title: Scrutiny of Microsoft scaled back
item.description: Brussels says it no longer needs full-time monitoring of Microsoft's compliance with a 2004 anti-trust ruling.

item.title: New guidelines on behavioural ads
item.description: Trades body draws up code of practice for targeted online advertisements that have been causing controversy.

item.title: ToysRUs pays $5m for toys domain
item.description: Toy giant ToysRUs pays a record amount for the Toys.com domain name as retailers look to make money online.

item.title: Bionic eye gives blind man sight
item.description: One of only three people in the UK to be fitted with a bionic eye talks about how he can see for the first time in 30 years.

item.title: The Briton who wrote an iPhone app in his bedroom
item.description: A man from London has been flown to America to develop and launch an application for the iPhone that he'd posted on YouTube after developing it in his bedroom.

item.title: Get your up-to-date fix of blog posts about all things digital
Cebit highlights
item.description: A look around the giant tech fair

item.title: Wikipedia vandals
item.description: The things they say about MPs and the battle to stop them

item.title: Status change
item.description: Facebook revamps to match Twitter

item.title: The Tech Lab
item.description: What Bono's sunglasses have to do with history

item.title: Hi-tech heist
item.description: One of the biggest attempted bank thefts in UK history

item.title: Risk jockeys
item.description: Pirates talk about what they do and why they do it

item.title: Green light for faster broadband
item.description: Regulator Ofcom rules that BT can proceed with the roll-out of a high-speed fibre-optic broadband network.

item.title: Pirate radio 'puts lives at risk'
item.description: Authorities are increasing efforts to crack down on pirate radio stations in the UK, saying they "could put lives at risk".

item.title: Pirate Bay awaits court verdict
item.description: The trial of the four men behind the Pirate Bay file-sharing site has come to an end.

item.title: UK video game firms call for help
item.description: The UK's video game makers need tax breaks, better trained staff and easier access to finance, says a report.

item.title: Slump in school computer lessons
item.description: Fewer English children are taking qualifications in information technology despite its economic importance, Ofsted says.

item.title: British 'careless' with liberties
item.description: Britons have been "careless" with their civil liberties, but that is changing, the former shadow home affairs minister says.

item.title: The cloud aids solo rowing bid
item.description: How hi-tech aids a bid to row round the world

item.title: Making the PC really personal
item.description: For some a beige box is just the beginning

item.title: Who does own user info and data
item.description: Many websites operate very different terms and conditions which govern what they will do with the information users submit.

item.title: How The Pirate Bay sailed into infamy
item.description: The Pirate Bay was launched in 2003 and quickly became popular with file-sharers. But now its founders are in court in Sweden.

item.title: Brega beats take Brazil by storm
item.description: Tecnobrega takes Brazil by storm

item.title: TED on porn, bugs and 'bots
item.description: Why Bill Gates let mosquitoes loose on a conference

item.title: Brightest tech brains meet in LA
item.description: Latest in tech discussed at TED conference

item.title: Facebook clocks fifth birthday
item.description: In five short years, Facebook has helped a global change in the way people keep in touch with one another.

item.title: Looking back to Apple's future
item.description: Makers of the first Macintosh look back at what they did

item.title: Score one for public openness
item.description: Regular commentator Bill Thompson looks at how the internet is helping make politics more open.

item.title: The drawbacks of new technology
item.description: Regular commentator Bill Thompson discusses the possible implications of new technology in developing nations

item.title: Having a connected Christmas
item.description: Regular commentator Bill Thompson discusses how he used social networking sites to stay in touch with friends and family over Christmas

item.title: Net politics is all rock and role
item.description: Regular commentator Bill Thompson on what an art project tells us about motivating the online masses.

item.title: The net and the real cost of free
item.description: Regular commentator Bill Thompson on what the free market might mean for all the data we surrender.

item.title: Moving to the Second Classroom
item.description: Regular commentator Bill Thompson on how the classroom can make its way in the virtual world.

item.title: Code-cracking and computers
item.description: Best known for its code-cracking work, Bletchley Park also played a role in the origins of the computer age.

item.title: Accelerating the modern age
item.description: A technology that helps the modern world keep running celebrates its 40th anniversary on 5 August.

item.title: One tonne 'Baby' marks its birth
item.description: The sixtieth anniversary of the birth of the first modern computer - known as Baby - is celebrated.

item.title: The history of UK computing
item.description: The UK's role in the early days of the computer revolution have been overlooked, say conservationists.

item.title: Alarm raised on teenage hackers
item.description: Computer security experts warn that many teenagers are falling into a life of petty cyber crime.

item.title: Hackers ready superstore sweep
item.description: Cyber thieves are hatching a plan to steal US funds through British supermarkets, the BBC learns.

item.title: What makes a cyber criminal?
item.description: Misha Glenny meets one of Brazil's many cyber criminals, to find out what makes them go online to steal.

item.title: Thieves set up data supermarkets
item.description: Cyber criminals are setting up web shops that sell stolen data for a knock-down price, say security experts.

item.title: Q&A: Stay safe online
item.description: ID fraud is a growing problem in the UK - here are some tips and tricks to help web users stay safe online.
